description: Amagane Rinne had an accident and died while hurrying to school. She suddenly arrived in an awkward school... in Hell, filled with demons. While she is struggling and wishing to go back to the world whence she came from, she makes friends with her demon schoolmates and develops an uncommon bond.

tags.name: Afterlife
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the afterlife.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Mythology
tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.name: Reincarnation
tags.description: Features a character being born again after death, typically as another person or in another world.

tags.name: Delinquents
tags.description: Features characters with a notorious image and attitude, sometimes referred to as "yankees".

tags.name: Werewolf
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a werewolf.

tags.name: Witch
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a witch.

tags.name: Isekai
tags.description: Features characters being transported into an alternate world setting and having to adapt to their new surroundings.

tags.name: Volleyball
tags.description: Centers around the sport of volleyball.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Zombie
tags.description: Prominently features reanimated corpses which often prey on live humans and turn them into zombies.

tags.name: Male Harem
tags.description: Main cast features the protagonist plus several male characters who are romantically interested in them.

tags.name: Religion
tags.description: Centers on the belief that humanity is related to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.

tags.name: Bullying
tags.description: Prominently features the use of force for intimidation, often in a school setting.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

node.description:
Aspired to become an animator simply because he wanted to draw for a living. Later enrolled to and graduated from Tokyo Animator Gakuin. He then joined [Magic Bus](https://anilist.co/studio/207/) and debuted as an in-betweener in 1987 under the studio's name on [God Bless Dancougar](https://anilist.co/anime/5266/). Nakazawa soon left Magic Bus and went freelance. In 1993, he was involved in the establishment of Studio G-1, an animation studio founded by [Masami Oobari](https://anilist.co/staff/100660/). During his time there he participated in many of [AIC](https://anilist.co/studio/48/)'s productions. Nakazawa got strongly influenced by Oobari during this time due to working under him on multiple occasions. Also unlike most animators at the time, Nakazawa wasn't really that shaped by [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s style, he was though, a huge fan of [Ichirou Itano](https://anilist.co/staff/103268/)'s and [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/)'s.

In 2002, Nakazawa made his directorial debut with Comedy, part of an anthology titled [Sweat Punch](https://anilist.co/anime/1072/), produced by [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/). The following year he directed both [Parasite Dolls](https://anilist.co/anime/1350/) jointly with [Naoyuki Yoshinaga](https://anilist.co/staff/115038/), as well as the animated part in Quentin Tarantino's movie, Kill Bill: Volume 1. This brought him a lot of international praise. He then got reached out to by director [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/) of [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/) fame, about the possiblity of taking part in the director's next work, [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/). Nakazawa accepted the offer and ended up being a crucial part of its production, handling the character designs and serving as the sole chief animation director on the show. He also directed, storyboarded and wrote the 15th episode. Ten years later in 2014, Nakazawa collaborated with Watanabe for the second time on [Terror in Resonance](https://anilist.co/anime/20661/), providing the character designs and working as an animation director on the series.

In recent years he has been closely involved with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大野広司)

1977, he joined Kobayashi Production, where he studied under [Shichirou Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/103964/). In 1982, he debuted as an art director on [Tonde Mon Pe](https://anilist.co/anime/6730/), and soon after that he left Kobayashi Production and took part in the founding of Studio Fuga with [Hiromasa Ogura](https://anilist.co/staff/105312/) and [Toshiharu Mizutani](https://anilist.co/staff/121908/). Later became, and is the current representative director of the studio.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/136171134)

A long-serving anime producer, as well as a founder of [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/) and [Studio M2](https://anilist.co/studio/6137/). He currently serves as the Chairman of the Board at [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/).

Maruyama graduated from Hosei University in 1963, and soon after, he found work at [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1965. It was here that he met many of Madhouse's future staff members. In October 1972, he left Mushi Production together with [Rintarou](https://anilist.co/staff/102305/), [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/) and founded Madhouse. From that time onward, Maruyama focused mainly on producing and planning Madhouse's upcoming projects. He also served as the studio's president through the '80s and '90s.

Thanks in large part to his frequent attendance at anime conventions, he has become well-known in America among Madhouse's fanbase. Not simply wanting to emulate past successes, Maruyama frequently says at these events that his goal as a producer is to seek out new challenges that will allow the production staff to keep experimenting. This attitude in part has been the reason why he has encouraged the studio to take on projects that may not seem like sure-fire commercial hits. In addition, Maruyama has long been a supporter of bringing new talents into the animation business, and continues to encourage young people to work in anime.

In 2011, he left Madhouse and founded Mappa. Later in 2016, he left Mappa and founded Studio M2.

(Source: Wikipedia)

Affiliated with [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) since 2002.

Debuted as a character designer on [Boogiepop and Others](https://anilist.co/anime/101283/).

[Twitter](https://x.com/sawa_zawazawa)

This brought him a lot of international praise. He then got reached out to by director [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/) of [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/) fame, about the possiblity of taking part in the director's next work, [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/). name.native: ジェイミー･ヴィッカーズ

node.description: Highly praised for his mechanical drawings by [Hiroyuki Okiura](https://anilist.co/staff/103502/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/75655903) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/something_Yoshimatsu/)

Affiliated with Studio Live since 1982. Studied under [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/). He has deep ties into [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) ever since working as a character designer on [Trigun](https://anilist.co/anime/6/) in 1998. A member of the Japanese Animation Creators Association (JAniCA).

Works as a mangaka under the name Something Yoshimatsu (サムシング吉松).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/e8144) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/eunyoung_tokyo)

Eun-Yeong Choi is an animator, director and producer. Since 2020, she is the President and CEO of the animation studio [Science SARU](https://anilist.co/studio/6145/), which she co-founded with [Masaaki Yuasa](https://anilist.co/staff/100068/) in 2013. A frequent collaborator with Yuasa, she has been involved in all of his projects since _[Kemonozume](https://anilist.co/anime/1454/)_ (2006).

Choi began her career as an animator on shows such as _[Witchblade](https://anilist.co/anime/935/)_, _[Black Lagoon](https://anilist.co/anime/889/)_ and _Kemonozume_ (all 2006). She made her directorial debut in 2008 on episodes of _[Kaiba](https://anilist.co/anime/3701/)_, and later worked as assistant director on _[Kick-Heart](https://anilist.co/anime/16149/)_ (2013). Choi transitioned to producer in 2017, beginning with _[The Night Is Short, Walk On Girl](https://anilist.co/anime/97917/)_. In 2021, she returned to directing, helming an episode of _Star Wars: Visions_.

_Note: Not to be confused with the [writer](https://anilist.co/staff/249891) or the younger [animator](https://anilist.co/staff/283043)._

[Website](http://qbo.sakura.ne.jp/masahiko/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/macha_mkun) | [Flickr](https://www.flickr.com/people/39493978@N08/)

In recent years he has also been working as still photographer.
